Next to Subcontinent Face-Off, the Cold War Looks Safe
1998-07-20T05:00:00.000Z
U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott will resume talks in New Delhi Monday with Jaswant Singh, the Indian government's point man in defending its nuclear tests to the world.
Their meeting comes amid signs of increasing realism in Washington about the rationale behind the tests, and about the limits of international sanctions as an instrument for effecting a policy change in New Delhi.
In turn, two months after their tit-for-tat nuclear weapons tests, it is dawning on many Indians and Pakistanis that their net security has been degraded, their economy damaged and their status diminished.
Mr. Talbott would do well to impress upon his Subcontinental hosts just how dangerous the nuclear relationship between India and Pakistan is compared with that between the Soviet Union and the United States in the Cold War.
Cold War deterrence was itself more unstable than realized at the time.
In the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, for example, the U.S. strategy was based on the best available intelligence, which indicated that there were no nuclear warheads in Cuba. In fact there were more than 100 warheads already stationed there, and the local Soviet commander had taken them out of storage to deployed positions for use against an American invasion. The thought of India-Pakistan relations being as stable as Cold War deterrence is not very reassuring.
The geostrategic environment of the Subcontinent has no parallel in the Cold War. India and Pakistan share a long border; the United States and the Soviet Union did not. This dramatically shortens the time frame either country would have to decide, during a crisis or war, whether to use nuclear weapons.
The entire province of Kashmir, the source of two of the three wars India and Pakistan have fought since their independence from Britain in 1947, remains in bitter contention, whereas the United States and the Soviet Union had no direct territorial dispute.
Contiguity permits India and Pakistan to meddle in each other's territory on a scale that was never an option for the United States and the Soviet Union during the Cold War.
India also shares a long border with nuclear-armed China; it, too, is disputed. This introduces a third element of territorial tension into the strategic equation, which was never the case in the Cold War.
The stability of Cold War deterrence rested on credible second-strike retaliatory capability. Stockpiles, command and control centers and the military-political leadership were protected against a surprise attack that could destroy all of them in one strike. Neither India nor Pakistan has even the most rudimentary basing, command and control systems in place that could survive a nuclear assault. Such an infrastructure could take one or two years to develop and install.
Moscow and Washington spread their stockpiles across land (on missiles), sea (on submarines) and air (on planes). This three-pronged dispersal added to detection and strike difficulties for an enemy and so buttressed second-strike capability. India and Pakistan lack this stabilizing triad of weapons platforms.
Because of the lack of survivable forces and command centers, both nations are highly vulnerable to a preemptive strike. But there is an inherent asymmetry in the way each calculates risks.
Pakistan cannot match India's conventional superiority. However, a successful first strike could destroy India's nuclear capability and paralyze its conventional superiority, thereby allowing Pakistan to avenge its defeat in the 1971 war over Bangladesh and wrest Kashmir from India — or so a government in Islamabad might conclude.
Conversely, a government in New Delhi might conclude that since reciprocal nuclear capability rules out their actual use by either country, it is safe to launch a military strike against Pakistan in punishment for its provocations in Kashmir. There is nothing in the history of the U.S.-Soviet relationship to indicate the eventual outcome of such an adventure.
Finally, all these worries are exacerbated by political volatility in both countries. The government of Pakistan faces economic meltdown and political challenges from Islamist groups and the military.
The government of India is an uneasy coalition of an intensely nationalist party that bases its legitimacy in religion and mythology, and a number of disparate parties that pursue different, and sometimes incompatible, regional agendas.
In the 51st year of India's independence, the governing Hindu nationalist party — heir to the fanatic movement that spawned Mahatma Gandhi's assassin — has betrayed the apostle of nonviolence by coveting the most horrific weapon of mass violence. And this when India has the highest number of poor and illiterate in the world.
No food, no clothing, no shelter? Don't worry, we have the bomb.
-
The writer is a vice rector at the United Nations University in Tokyo. He contributed this comment to the International Herald Tribune.

PUBLIC LIVES; Honoring Immigrants, and How They Lived
1998-12-17T05:00:00.000Z
RUTH ABRAM'S life is the story of how personal hurts grew into a museum that no one ever imagined.
It started on a bus in Atlanta in the early 1950's, when the Abram family maid, Rosa May Maddox, found a seat for young Ruth in the front, then moved to the back. In 1958, when Ruth was 13, she was told at her private Atlanta school that she could not join the cotillion because she was Jewish. Soon after, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. came to her home -- her father is Morris Abram, the legendary civil rights lawyer -- her parents said it was best not to tell her friends.
Much later, when Ms. Abram found an Orthodox synagogue in Riverdale for the education of her children, the rabbi informed her that she was not Jewish at all. Why? Because Ms. Abram's mother, a one-time Methodist, had converted to Judaism only after Ms. Abram's birth.
''It sort of felt like I was being spun out into the universe, with no anchor,'' Ms. Abram said.
So it is not a complete surprise that Ms. Abram, 53, is the founder and president of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, an institution that celebrates immigrants -- and which Ms. Abram sees as ''promoting the kind of tolerance that wouldn't permit the things I experienced.''
Last month, the decade-old museum -- housed in a five-story Orchard Street apartment building that from 1863 to 1935 was home to about 10,000 people from 25 countries -- became a ''national historic area'' and part of the National Park Service, meaning it can now apply for Federal funds. The month before, the tenement building was designated a site of the National Trust for Historic Preservation. So far, it is the only Trust site in America that was not the home of someone rich or famous. (New York has two other Trust sites: Kykuit, the Rockefeller estate, and Lyndhurst, the home of Jay Gould, the financier and swindler.)
Ms. Abram, needless to say, is in a very good mood. There is the prospect of more money, and visitors. There is also the realization that she is running the only tenement museum in the country, and helping to change the idea of what is important to preserve in America. Her goal, someday, is to have the museum be a stop for tourists after they see Ellis Island. ''I always say there's this great question,'' she said. '''What happened afterward?''
Ms. Abram talked last week in the drafty kitchen of the tenement house, where she was gracious and appropriate. She came alive, though, during a one-hour tour of the museum -- she still gives one a week -- for a group of a dozen or so. (Whose families came, they told her when she asked, from England, China, Peru, Bangladesh, Russia, Ireland, Sweden and Poland.) Ms. Abram started in the building's entrance hall, in total darkness and under peeling paint, just as it looked in 1863. ''Welcome home!'' she said. ''Come with me.''
THERE followed a tour of the museum's permanent exhibit, opened last week, of the apartment of the Rogarshevskys, a family of Orthodox Jewish immigrants from Lithuania, who lived in three rooms re-created to look as they did on July 12, 1918, after Abraham Rogarshevsky, a 45-year-old garment presser, died of tuberculosis. There was medicine on the table by his bed, and bagels and bialys brought by friends. Ms. Abram calls the Rogarshevskys and their neighbors ''our urban pioneers.''
The Rogarshevsky apartment is the fourth of 20 in the building to be restored. The most recent in time is that of Adolpho and Rosaria Baldizzi, Catholic immigrants from Sicily, who lost their jobs during the Depression and were evicted in 1935. Ms. Abram told her tour that the Baldizzi apartment, re-created to look as it did on the day they were thrown out, was filled with authentic belongings taken from the apartment by the Baldizzis' daughter, Josephine, who lived there as a child and died a few months ago.
Just before the apartment opened to the public, Ms. Abram said, Josephine came to see it. ''And she got right here, and she burst into tears,'' Ms. Abram said. Josephine Baldizzi requested only one change: That she be allowed to iron and neatly pack the clothes displayed in the suitcases on the apartment floor. ''My mamma was fastidious!'' Josephine told Ms. Abram. ''Even for eviction, she never would have thrown things together in the haphazard way you packed!''
Ms. Abram lives on the Upper West Side, is married to Herbert Teitelbaum, a partner at Robinson Silverman, has two grown children, was a social worker and a women's rights organizer, graduated from Sarah Lawrence College, has a master's degree in American history from New York University and apologized for being boring in an interview.
Her most vivid memory of Dr. King? ''What I remember more than anything is going to the Abyssinian Baptist Church to hear him preach, and what he was saying to the congregation was 'support your children.' In other words, your children will be doing things you don't want, but there is a higher law. And it had an incredible effect on me. Because of all the places to try to change people's minds, to do that in your own community is harder.''
Ms. Abram's forbears were from Romania, Prussia, Ireland and Scotland. Despite her pedigree, she says her museum has made her feel as if she has ''come home'' ---- to a place where Americans can ''meet our families before they became acceptable.''

Clinton Packs Up His Care and Woe To Trot the Globe
1998-03-23T05:00:00.000Z
President Clinton left the country today. And you had better get used to it.
The 12-day trip to Africa that Mr. Clinton began today is not merely the longest foreign visit of his Presidency; it is also the first in a series of trips that will sweep him away to four continents in four months. Those travels will keep him out of the country for more than four weeks between now and early July.
All in all, not a bad itinerary for a fellow under fire from an independent counsel, assorted lawyers and a pack of Congressmen who have taken to occasional mutterings about impeachment.
''I believe he's looking forward to his trip,'' the President's lawyer, Robert S. Bennett, said mildly on Friday, as the latest wave in the Paula Corbin Jones case crashed over his head.
Cynics, wags and Republicans have been quick to invoke a time-tested political rule to explain Presidential wanderlust, citing the example of President Richard M. Nixon's 1974 visit to Egypt during his Watergate turmoil.
''If you're in trouble, go abroad,'' said Lyn Nofziger, the former strategist for President Ronald Reagan. ''It changes the subject pretty thoroughly.''
But advisers to Mr. Clinton dismiss that idea, noting that while his schedule has been rearranged and expanded a bit in recent weeks, most of his overseas destinations for the year were picked long before Ms. Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit against him made Monica S. Lewinsky a household name.
Weighty matters of foreign policy -- not the tangled wranglings of domestic politics and legal actions, White House aides insist, with some exasperation, are what have turned the President into a rolling stone.
Which is not to say that the White House is unhappy at the prospect of television's carrying images of Mr. Clinton preoccupied with affairs of global security and economics, and standing beside the likes of Nelson Mandela, the President of South Africa.
''Pictures of the President as a world leader are always nice,'' an Administration official conceded, on condition of anonymity.
But, he added, that is far from the reason for Mr. Clinton's trip to Africa.
''It's something that he's always wanted to do, and he feels that it's an important part of the world that doesn't get enough attention,'' this official said.
In fact, Presidential trips themselves do not receive the attention they once did. With the cold war over, superpower prestige, ego and security are no longer perceived to depend as much on the fates of tiny countries, including some African ones Mr. Clinton is visiting.
Partly to insure some coverage of the trip back home, the Administration has loaded the President up with what officials call ''deliverables'' -- new programs, like increased financing for education and food security, for Mr. Clinton to announce. White House aides also note that the trip has already received widespread attention among American blacks, one of the Democrats' most important constituencies.
''There are audience segments that pay a lot of attention,'' another White House aide said.
Further, officials said, they have learned that Mr. Clinton can generate news on a domestic issue, like the budget, just as easily from abroad.
Whatever the vagaries of coverage and political reaction in the United States, Presidents are assured a personal boost from wall-to-wall foreign coverage and from ecstatic crowds lining motorcade routes and filling cobbled or dirt plazas.
''Foreign travel does a lot for a President under siege in terms of his own psyche,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the former press secretary for Presidents Reagan and George Bush. ''Every President enjoys traveling in foreign countries because it makes him feel like a President again.''
After focusing his first Presidential campaign on domestic issues, Mr. Clinton found himself, to his aggravation and occasional dismay, repeatedly distracted in his first term by foreign policy crises like Somalia. But he has grown to relish his foreign policy duties, aides say, and no longer feels the need to rely on more experienced mentors in his decision-making. He is said to love the travel and the opportunities it provides to soak up information, trivia and stories.
After his trip to Africa, Mr. Clinton plans to go to Latin America next month for the Summit of the Americas in Santiago, Chile. In May, he plans to go to Birmingham, England, for an annual economic summit meeting. The White House has been adding stops to that trip, including a visit to Berlin before and perhaps one to Northern Ireland at the end. And while he is in Europe, Mr. Clinton just might bop over to Moscow.
The President is expected to be back in the United States in plenty of time for the Jones trial, which is scheduled to begin on May 27 in Little Rock, Ark. Having already given a deposition, he does not have to testify in the trial. But his advisers are holding open the option of having him appear in his own defense.
Then, in June, Mr. Clinton is off again. He is planning to make a 10-day trip to China, beginning near the end of that month.
The China trip was originally scheduled for November, but last week the White House moved it up, saying the President was eager to preserve momentum in relations with China. White House aides insisted the change in plans had nothing to do with the Jones trial.
Later in the year, Mr. Clinton plans a trip to India, Pakistan and Bangladesh, as well as one to Malaysia.
The Africa trip is planned to be the longest of the year -- indeed, the longest foreign tour of any President at least since Mr. Reagan went to Europe in the spring of 1985. White House aides said the schedule was driven by Mr. Clinton's desire to make what he has called the first ''serious trip to Africa'' of any President.
''If you're going to do this,'' a senior Administration official said, ''to have the story be all the places you didn't go versus all the places you did go would be to pay a big price for not spending a couple of extra days.'' As it is, Mr. Clinton will still visit only 6 of the 48 sub-Saharan countries: Ghana, Uganda, Rwanda, South Africa, Botswana and Senegal.
Mr. Clinton's advisers describe African nations as poised for extraordinary growth the way Asian countries were in the 1960's and 70's.
''So many of these countries are at a lift-off point,'' the Administration official said. Decades hence, this official and others believe, the visit may appear to be a historic moment, cementing American and African ties.
Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, said, ''One of the overriding goals of this trip is to help Americans rethink Africa, and Africans rethink America.''
For all the high-minded foreign policy goals, some Clinton advisers expect little to change in their daily routines besides the food and the scenery. The 800-member traveling delegation includes scores of reporters attuned to the continuing investigations back home.
Asked at a news conference if there was no ''side benefit'' to Mr. Clinton's ''getting out of town for a couple of weeks,'' Mr. Berger said, ''Well, you come with us.''
Some aides hold out the hope that reporters might get a dose of perspective upon witnessing the troubles of some African nations.
''They don't have the luxury of getting diverted to the kinds of stories we've gotten diverted to in the last eight weeks,'' a Clinton adviser said.
But because reporters have had little chance to question Mr. Clinton about his relationship with Ms. Lewinsky and recent developments in the investigations, White House aides expect a joint news conference by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Mandela on Friday to turn into a circus.
''It's probably a safe bet,'' one of Mr. Clinton's advisers said sourly.
That is one event for which the White House seems rather uninterested in generating much of an audience. It is scheduled for 11:20 A.M. in Cape Town -- 4:20 A.M. in Washington.

Traveler's Notebook; Have Adapter, Will Travel
1998-09-24T05:00:00.000Z
IN the old days, travel meant getting away. Now it means going, but not getting away. To explore the third world may still mean lugging a backpack, but inside it you can have a trove of high-tech devices that tether you as securely to the first world as a ball and chain.
When I set off for the hinterlands these days, I sometimes still pull out the same dark blue Eagle Creek backpack that I used 15 years ago as a graduate student. But in those days I would simply step out of some Asian or African airport, put on my cool sunglasses, heave the backpack onto my shoulders and disappear for five weeks at a time.
Now the backpack is the same, but everything in it has changed. The most important transformation is that it can now serve as a communications center.
The centerpiece is my Thrane & Thrane satellite phone, which I can set up in about 30 seconds in the middle of a jungle clearing. Satellite phones are expensive -- one costs about $3,000, which doesn't include charges of about $2.50 a minute for calls -- but they allow voice and data transmission from any place on the planet outside the polar zones. When the light plane I was riding in lost the use of its controls in Uganda last year and was coming down for a crash landing without even being able to dump its fuel first, I braced myself in crash position and grimly contemplated the expected fireball -- then realized that I might have time before the crash to pull out the satellite phone and use my laptop to buy extra life insurance off the World Wide Web.
Progress is comforting.
A half-dozen years ago, satellite phones were suitcase-size contraptions with huge antennas, and they required a large amount of electrical power. But in the current generation, a satellite phone is the size of a laptop computer and works from a battery pack. In contrast with cellular phones, which function only if a ground station is nearby, a satellite phone can be used almost anywhere.
You point a satellite phone at the sky, turn it on and rotate it until you find the satellite that best serves the area. The line is slow for data, 2,400 baud, and there is a slight lag in conversations as the signals go up to the satellite and back, but the battery will give you nearly two hours' worth of phone conversation or an hour of E-mail transmission.
When the battery goes out on my Thrane & Thrane, a solar panel is available to recharge it. But for juice, I always pack a portable power inverter that I picked up from Radio Shack. It is a device that plugs into a car's cigarette lighter at one end and offers a regular 110-volt electrical outlet at the other end. So as long as there is a car around, I can power up my laptop and satellite telephone -- and electric shaver.
(A cautionary tale: In a remote part of Congo, I once ran a satellite phone from a car battery and then tried to drive off. But the phone had drained the battery dead, and I was on a dirt road in guerrilla-held territory in the middle of a civil war. The moral of the story is to always keep the engine running when you borrow from a car battery.)
For following the news, I also carry a little Sony shortwave radio, scarcely bigger than a cigarette pack. I've been through many versions, and although my current one is a neat digital version that also functions as an alarm clock, the key element is an accompanying antenna with a clip at one end so it can be hooked onto a hotel curtain or window. Good shortwave reception depends not on a $300 radio but on a $10 antenna.
My communications center also includes a couple of phone cables, including a device called a spider that has a United States-style telephone plug at one end for my laptop and divides into eight arms with plugs for different kinds of phone systems at the other. Ever since a desperate struggle with a phone system in Macao many years ago, I also carry alligator clips to connect my modem directly into the phone cables if all else fails: I unscrew the phone outlet from the wall and poke around until I find the phone wires.
For all this reconnaissance work on phone lines, I carry around a little screwdriver set that I got in Korea a decade ago to take apart the telephones in the Chosun Hotel. The screwdrivers have stubby ends so airline security officials will not confiscate them as weapons, and I also carry folding scissors and a miniature pocketknife that airlines regard as less threatening than my Swiss Army knife. I avoid checking bags on flights, so that makes it impossible to carry anything that bothers the people who cluster around airport X-ray machines.
Rounding out my communications center is a convertible plug set that I got for about $10 at Heathrow Airport to deal with wall outlets in various foreign countries and a small Radio Shack device that plugs into the phone line at one end and my little tape recorder at the other, allowing me to tape phone interviews. (It's the same device that Linda Tripp used, I believe, but unlike Ms. Tripp, I get permission before I tape calls.)
Moving from the communications center to the bedroom, I carry some low-tech gadgetry in the third world to make sure that I survive long enough to play with the high-tech toys. I sleep inside a sheet sack, which is a bit like a sleeping bag except that it is made out of a tightly woven sheet and keeps out bedbugs, and I pack a mosquito net as well. My current version is a wonderful device that folds up around my face like a little tent.
I once had to bivouac in Africa in an abandoned mud hut that turned out to have a wasp nest directly above my cot. My mosquito coils evidently had an effect on the wasps because they dropped on me all night, sick but not dead. I ended up covered by a layer of squirming wasps, but with my sheet sack and mosquito net, I ended up as snug as a bug in a rug. Well, O.K., as snug as a human covered with wasps, which is to say not so snug at all, but it could have been worse.
Since catching malaria last year, I have been on the warpath against mosquitoes. So now I also pack disgusting insect repellents that have a hefty concentration of DEET and also a substance called Duranon to treat clothing, keeping insects away for two weeks even after the clothing is washed. In malarial areas, I also take a nifty Japanese thingamajig (not available anywhere else, as far as I know) that snaps onto your belt and holds a burning mosquito coil, which puffs merrily as you walk around.
None of that is effective against rats and roaches, which are my bane. I once settled into a cheap hotel room in Bangladesh and found it infested with thousands of two-inch cockroaches crawling all over the bed and floor. I packed a small can of roach spray on my next Bangladesh trip. But that was a luxury and in any case, I've stopped carrying sprays ever since an embarrassing incident in a tiny airport in southwestern China. When a security guard there found my spray deodorant, he held it up before a throng of hundreds of curious Chinese and asked me suspiciously what I intended to use it for.
Deodorant is unknown in rural China, and the term for deodorant in Chinese literally means ''chemical to drive away the stink.'' So it was a bit awkward to explain to the crowd that I used such a chemical on myself and that otherwise I would begin to smell. Hundreds of pairs of eyes gazed at me in fascination, and noses began twitching curiously. I have never again packed a spray can in my carry-on luggage.
My kitchen is the smallest section of the pack. It consists simply of an iodine dropper to purify water -- a few drops are supposed to kill even amoebic dysentery -- and a military-issue can opener, a great little gadget scarcely bigger than a paper clip. I gave my first one away to a Bedouin who treated me to dinner over his campfire in the Sinai many years ago, and I've gone through several since then.
For times when the electricity goes out, I pack a couple of small candles and matches. Then there's always either a miniflashlight or a slightly larger flashlight that converts into a lantern.
Moving from the office, bedroom and kitchen to the front door, I prefer a profusion of low-tech devices to make sure that my pack stays in my possession. In India a dozen years ago, I once lost the key to the minipadlock on my pack and was horrified to discover how easily I could jimmy it open with a screwdriver. So I went to a locksmith and bought a dozen much stouter padlocks that all take the same key, and now I use those hefty locks and keep a few copies of the key secreted here and there. I also carry a bicycle lock and run it through the padlocks and then lock it to something sturdy if I am in a cheap hotel.
The silliest place to carry money and a passport, of course, is in one's pocket or a purse, but I also lost my faith in the common waist and neck pouches after running into a Canadian man on a train in the Ivory Coast. A big hefty man (he was a professional basketball player), he had been set upon when he had first stepped onto the train. The first thing the robbers did was to rip open his shirt and grab the waist pouch containing his money and passport. The problem with those pouches is that they leave a visible bulge under one's shirt and tell thieves where to look.
So in bad areas, I carry my passport and other essentials in a leather pouch that loops around my belt and then slips down against my leg on the inside of my trousers. It's almost impossible to detect unless somebody pulls down my pants, which has not happened so far (even if some drunken Ghanaian soldiers, in the course of robbing us, once made a traveling companion pull off his shoes and socks so they could check for hidden money). In unstable areas, I also wear a nifty black leather belt that looks like any other but has a zipper on the inside; I keep two $100 bills folded there. Then, even if everything is stolen, I can at least pay any lifesaving bribes and get transportation to an American embassy.
Another essential is a decoy wallet because it is only polite when you encounter an angry soldier with a machine gun to allow yourself to be robbed. So I have a wallet in my hip pocket with some local currency and a library card for identification (it's amazing what checkpoints an English-language library card will get you through). The problem is that it is easy to forget that the wallet is just a decoy, meant to be taken.
One time when I was walking with a friend through a slum in Lima, Peru, a mugger grabbed my friend's decoy wallet, which had only about $10 in it. We should have let the mugger take it, but instead we wrestled around on the ground with the mugger as a crowd gathered. Finally the mugger ran off empty-handed, and a mysterious man emerged and began firing a pistol in the general direction of the fleeing thief.
We had not counted on guns, and the episode had escalated much more quickly than we had expected. We felt rather foolish explaining that there had been almost nothing in the wallet, and I suppose that the incident illustrated the importance of something even more important than a low-tech decoy wallet or a high-tech satellite phone: non-tech common sense.

South Asians Lament Economic Rifts
1998-08-03T05:00:00.000Z
When the seven nations of South Asia held a summit meeting in Sri Lanka last week, their leaders engaged in what has become an annual lament, acknowledging that the region has been an economic backwater for decades. Ending their three-day meeting on Friday, they vowed, as they have at such meetings for years, to hasten efforts to break down economic barriers among them.
But as they headed home, the leaders were faced with a barrage of skepticism. Throughout India, Pakistan and Bangladesh -- the three large nations in the grouping -- and Bhutan, Nepal, Sri Lanka and the Maldives, critics have despaired of ending the suspicions and enmities that have blocked economic ties that could help lift their people out of poverty.
This time, the disappointments had a ready focus in the failure of India and Pakistan to agree on resuming talks aimed at bridging the region's largest rift. The two nations demonstrated again, after several rounds of abrasive talks about talks, how difficult they have found it to reconcile themselves to the bitter events of 50 years ago, when Hindus and Muslims -- unable to agree on terms for living together -- opted to carve separate countries out of what had been British India.
What was to have been the crowning event of the summit meeting, a handshake sealing an agreement on new talks, became a moment for the two Governments to exchange old grievances over Kashmir, the territory divided between them at the partition of the subcontinent in 1947.
India's Prime Minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, accused Pakistan of engaging in ''fantasies'' and ''propaganda'' over Kashmir; Pakistan's Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, said India's refusal to make Kashmir the priority issue in talks meant that the two leaders were ''wasting each other's time.'' The meeting closed with a sense of failure.
Among other things, the standoff appeared to mean that India and Pakistan will not hold early discussions on ways of lessening the risk of a nuclear war, the issue that dominated discussion in the corridors of the summit meeting. Because of a stipulation in the regional group's charter that precludes discussion of politically divisive issues between member states, the nuclear tests conducted by India and Pakistan in May were not on the agenda and were not mentioned in the concluding communique.
Mr. Vajpayee set the pattern with a speech that mentioned the nuclear tests only obliquely, referring to them as ''recent events in South Asia,'' and then only to say that there was no reason for the tests to impede new regional economic ties. President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga of Sri Lanka, the meeting's host, held to the protocol forbidding discussion of contentious issues, but made her own feelings clear. Calling for an ''ambiance of confidence'' in the region, she added, ''It cannot be denied that such an ambiance could be affected by recent developments.''
A leading Sri Lanka newspaper, The Island, captured the gloomy mood of the group, the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation, with an editorial today headed, ''S.A.A.R.C. at a Dead End.'' ''Ten years of summitry has not brought any tangible results to the billion people of the region,'' the editorial said, adding that if political hostilities continue to thwart economic cooperation, the organization's reason to exist ''is in question.''
Some optimists said that even if the meeting did go aground over the hostilities between India and Pakistan, it had served a purpose in underlining the region's dismal economic state. Several of the leaders noted that the region, with a combined population of 1.3 billion people, has the world's largest concentration of poverty. According to figures quoted here, at least 40 percent of the region's people live without adequate shelter, food, education or medical care or even safe drinking water.
Of the nations that attended the summit, only the Maldives, with a thriving tourist industry, has a per capita income as high as $500 a year.
The point was made forcefully by Mr. Vajpayee, on his first trip outside India since becoming the country's leader after elections in March. ''We represent great civilizations, ancient yet vibrant and alive, and yet we are among the poorest in the world,'' he said. He made a plea for change: ''Enough of sterile ideology. Enough of hostile nationalism. Enough of conflict on the basis of religion and creed. Enough of poverty and backwardness. Let us grow rich together.''
For many years, India was considered the obstacle to closer regional ties. But at the Colombo meeting, India led the way in pushing for lowering trade barriers, announcing that it would eliminate restrictions that have severely limited imports from its neighbors of more than 2,000 products.
The seven nations also renewed their commitment to establish a South Asian free trade area by the year 2001, but many participants seemed doubtful that the goal could be met. A preferential trading area, under which each member state agreed to make concessions to the others not available to other nations, has been bogged down in red tape since it was established in 1993.
According to Indian statistics, only 3.7 percent of the region's total foreign trade of about $140 billion is from trade among the South Asian nations, which trade primarily with Japan, Europe and the United States.
As an example of the disfunctional economic arrangements in the region, others at the meeting noted that Pakistan imports iron ore from Australia, Canada and Brazil, while India has a surplus it exports to Japan. Other examples abounded.
Privately, officials attending the meeting acknowledged that achieving economic momentum among their countries is unlikely until political tensions abate.
